title: Bishop Score for Vaginal Delivery and Induction of Labor
description: Predicts likelihood of successful vaginal delivery and determines favorable cervical conditions for labor induction in pregnant women at term

parameters.name: cervical_dilation
parameters.description: Cervical dilation measured in centimeters during pelvic examination

parameters.name: fetal_station
parameters.description: Fetal station - position of baby's presenting part relative to ischial spines

parameters.name: cervical_position
parameters.description: Position of the cervix relative to the fetal head and vaginal axis

parameters.name: cervical_consistency
parameters.description: Consistency or firmness of the cervix on palpation

result.name: bishop_score
result.description: Bishop score for predicting successful vaginal delivery and labor induction

ranges.interpretation: Unfavorable cervix with low likelihood of successful vaginal delivery. Labor induction may be necessary and cervical ripening agents should be considered before induction. Higher risk of cesarean delivery.

ranges.description: Scores 6-7 are indeterminate for induction success
ranges.interpretation: Intermediate cervical favorability. Success of labor induction is uncertain. Clinical judgment should guide decision-making regarding timing and method of delivery. Consider individual patient factors and circumstances.
Favorable cervix with high likelihood of successful vaginal delivery. Spontaneous labor likely to occur soon or labor induction has good chance of success. Low risk of cesarean delivery.

references: Bishop EH. Pelvic scoring for elective induction. Obstet Gynecol. 1964 Aug;24:266-8.
Laughon SK, Zhang J, Troendle J, Sun L, Reddy UM. Using a simplified Bishop score to predict vaginal delivery. Obstet Gynecol. 2011 Apr;117(4):805-11.
Crane JM. Factors predicting labor induction success: a critical analysis. Clin Obstet Gynecol. 2006 Sep;49(3):573-84.
formula: Sum of scores from 5 components: Cervical dilation (0-3 points) + Effacement (0-3 points) + Fetal station (0-3 points) + Cervical position (0-2 points) + Cervical consistency (0-2 points). Total score range: 0-13 points
notes: Originally developed by Dr. Edward Bishop in 1964 to predict success of elective labor induction
Score should be assessed by experienced clinician through standardized pelvic examination
Commonly used to predict risk of cesarean section and guide labor management decisions
Scores ≤5: Unfavorable cervix, consider cervical ripening before induction
Scores 6-7: Indeterminate, use clinical judgment for induction timing
Scores ≥8: Favorable cervix, good candidate for labor induction
Score may change rapidly during active labor as cervical changes occur
Modified Bishop scores exist that include additional factors like maternal age and parity
Should be used in conjunction with other clinical factors and patient preferences
Not recommended for use before 37 weeks gestation or in high-risk pregnancies without obstetric consultation
